keyTakeAways: Virginia Giuffre, a former Epstein victim, claims in her posthumous memoir that she was raped by a 'well-known Prime Minister' (later identified as Prince Andrew) while under Epstein’s trafficking network.

The memoir alleges that Prince Andrew engaged in three sexual encounters with Giuffre, including when she was just 17 years old, and that he laughed when he harmed her, which Giuffre describes as deeply traumatic.

Prince Andrew denied the allegations and previously claimed he had broken off ties with Epstein in 2010, but new emails show he maintained contact through 2011, including messages indicating they were 'in this together'.
Giuffre claims that Prince Andrew’s team tried to hire online trolls to harass her during her civil case, attempting to discredit her credibility.
Prince Andrew reportedly paid millions to settle the civil case in 2022, which Giuffre says was a form of financial and symbolic compensation for the abuse and years of silence.
The memoir has reignited a transatlantic scandal linking powerful figures to Epstein’s sex-trafficking network, with significant implications for public trust in elite institutions.

The UK version of the memoir refers to the man as a 'former minister,' while the US version calls him a 'well-known Prime Minister,' creating a discrepancy that raises questions about official narratives and reporting accuracy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Virginia Giuffre, a victim of Jeffrey Epstein’s sex trafficking network, published her posthumous memoir 'Nobody’s Girl' in 2025, detailing that she was raped by a man she referred to as a 'well-known Prime Minister'—later identified as Prince Andrew—while being trafficked by Epstein. The memoir alleges that Prince Andrew sexually abused her when she was 17, laughed during acts of violence, and maintained contact with Epstein after claiming to have severed ties. Giuffre also claims that Prince Andrew’s team attempted to hire online trolls to harass her and that he paid millions to settle a civil case in 2022. The revelations have reignited a transatlantic scandal over elite power and abuse, undermining Prince Andrew’s credibility and deepening the public disgrace of the royal family, especially amid newly discovered emails contradicting his public statements about ending ties with Epstein.
